revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Text societies to [[:Category:Text publication societies]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
The '''British Record Society''' is a British [[learned society]] that focuses on publishing [[archive|historic records]], or, more specifically, [[Index (publishing)|indexes]] to such records. In recent years, the Society has concentrated on the publication of name indexes to English [[probate]] records, and the texts of 17th-century [[Hearth Tax]] returns.
==Foundation and early history== The Society was founded in 1889 to take over the [[Index Library]], which had begun life the previous year as [[William Phillimore Watts Phillimore|W.P.W. Phillimore's]] private scheme for the publication of indexes to British public records, which is now the brief of the List and Index Society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.listandindexsociety.org.uk |title=serving the historical community |publisher=List and Index Society |date= |accessdate=2013-06-05}}</ref> The Society was also always interested in record conservation, and to act as what would now be called a pressure group for [[archive]]s and their users, pushing for the creation of county record offices and county record societies. The inception of an official series of Lists and Indexes in 1892 reduced the need for private publication of indexes to records in the [[Public Record Office]]. The Society consequently turned its attention to records held in other repositories.
In 1898 the Society’s Scottish section became the totally independent [[Scottish Record Society]]. In 1933 the Society’s Record Preservation Section similarly took off to become the germ of the [[British Records Association]] (B.R.A).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishrecordsassociation.org.uk |title=British Records Association |publisher=British Records Association |date=2012-05-12 |accessdate=2013-06-05}}</ref>
==Activities== Since the 1930s, the British Record Society has been primarily a publishing society for English records, frequently in conjunction with county historical societies. By 2012, 126 volumes of the Index Library had been published over 123 years, besides two extra volumes and some microfiche. Over the past half century the Society has largely, but not exclusively, concentrated on the publication of name indexes to [[probate]] records, and the texts of [[Hearth Tax]] returns from the 1660s and 1670s.
A longer history of the Society and its current activities will be found on its website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britishrecordsociety.org |title=contact |publisher=Britishrecordsociety.org |date=2011-02-17 |accessdate=2013-06-05}}</ref>
A complete list of its publications up to 1982 will be found in E.L.C. Mullins, ''Texts and Calendars'', I and II, Royal Historical Society, 1958 and 1983. Details of those published after 1982 can be found on the [[Royal Historical Society]]'s website.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.royalhistoricalsociety.org/textandcalendars.htm |title=(RHS) |publisher=[[Royal Historical Society]] |date= |accessdate=2013-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614165832/http://www.royalhistoricalsociety.org/textandcalendars.htm |archivedate=2013-06-14 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Text publication society]]
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |ref=harv|editor1-first=G.H. |editor1-last=Martin |editor1-link=Geoffrey Martin (historian) |editor2-first=Peter |editor2-last=Spufford |title=The Records of the Nation: The Public Record Office 1838-1988: The British Record Society 1888-1988 |publisher=Boydell |place=Woodbridge UK/Rochester US |year=1990 |ISBN=0851155383 }} *{{cite book|ref=harv|last=Spufford |first=Peter |year=1976 |chapter=Marc Fitch and the British Record Society |editor1-first=F. G. |editor1-last=Emmison |editorlink1=F. G. Emmison |editor2-first=Roy |editor2-last=Stephens |title=Tribute to an antiquary: essays presented to Marc Fitch by some of his friends |place=London |publisher=Leopard's Head Press |ISBN=0904920003|pages= 9–19}}
==External links== * [http://www.britishrecordsociety.org British Record Society website]

{{no footnotes|date=February 2015}} '''Buyer credit''' is a short term [[Credit (finance)|credit]] available to an [[Importer|importer (buyer)]] from overseas lenders such as [[bank]]s and other [[financial institution]] for goods they are importing. The overseas banks usually lend the importer (buyer) based on the [[letter of comfort]] (a bank guarantee) issued by the importer's bank. For this service the importer's bank or buyer's credit consultant charges a fee called an arrangement fee.
Buyer's credit helps local importers gain access to cheaper foreign funds that may be closer to [[London Interbank Offered Rate|LIBOR]] rates as against local sources of funding which are more costly.
The duration of buyer's credit may vary from country to country, as per the local regulations. For example, in India, buyer's credit can be availed for one year in case the import is for tradeable goods and for three years if the import is for capital goods.
== Benefits to importer == Buyer's credit has several advantages for the importer. The exporter gets paid on due date; whereas importer gets extended date for making an import payment as per the cash flows. The importer can deal with exporter on sight basis, negotiate a better discount and use the buyers credit route to avail financing. The funding currency can be depending on the choice of the customer and availability of LIBOR rates in the exchange market. The importer can use this financing for any form of payment mode, such as: open account, collections, or LCs.
== Steps involved == # The customer requests the Buyer's Credit Arranger to arrange the credit before the due date of the bill # Arrange to request overseas bank branches to provide a buyer's credit offer letter in the name of the importer. Best rate of interest is quoted to the importer # Overseas bank to fund Importer's bank [[Nostro and vostro accounts|Nostro account]] for the required amount # Importer's bank to make import bill payment by utilizing the amount credited (if the borrowing currency is different from the currency of Imports then a cross currency contract is utilized to effect the import payment) # Importer's bank will recover the required amount from the importer and remit the same to overseas bank on due date. # It helps importer in working capital management.
== Cost involved == Interest cost is charged by overseas bank as a financing cost.
== Risk involved == Buyer's credit is associated with [[currency risk]]. Thus, [[Hedge (finance)|Hedging]] may be required as foreign currency is involved, making Buyer's Credit risky at times.
== Indian regulatory framework == Banks can provide buyer’s credit up to US$20 million (US$ 2 crore) per import transactions for a maximum maturity period of one year from date of shipment. In case of import of capital goods, banks can approve buyer’s credits up to $20 million per transaction with a maturity period of up to three years. No rollover beyond that period is permitted.
As per RBI directives dated 11.07.13, at the time of availment of trade credit, the period of trade credit should be linked to the operating cycle and trade transaction. AD banks need to ensure that these instructions are strictly complied with.
RBI has issued directions under Sec 10(4) and Sec 11(1) of the [[Foreign Exchange Management Act]], 1999, stating that authorized dealers may approve proposals received (in Form ECB) for short-term credit for financing—by way of either suppliers' credit or buyers' credit—of import of goods into India, based on uniform criteria. Credit is to be extended for a period of less than three years; amount of credit should not exceed $20 million, per import transaction; the `all-in-cost' per annum, payable for the credit is not to exceed 6 months LIBOR + 350 basis points for credit up to one year, and LIBOR + 125 basis points for credits for periods beyond one year but less than three years, for the currency of credit.
All applications for short-term credit exceeding $20 million for any import transaction are to be forwarded to the Chief General Manager, Exchange Control Department, [[Reserve Bank of India]], Central Office, External Commercial Borrowing (ECB) Division, Mumbai. Each credit has to be given `a unique identification number' by authorised dealers and the number so allotted should be quoted in all references. The International Banking Division of the authorised dealer is required to furnish the details of approvals granted by all its branches, during the month, in Form ECB-ST to the RBI, so as to reach not later than 5th of the following month. (Circular AP (DIR Series) No 24 dated September 27, 2002.
As per RBI Master circular on External Commercial Borrowing and Trade Finance 1 July 2011, the all-in cost ceiling for interest is now six month L + 200 {{Not a typo|bps}}(bps is Basis Points . A unit that is equal to 1/100th of 1%) for buyer's credit arrange for tenure up to three years. All cost ceiling includes arranger fee, upfront fee, management fee, handling and processing charges, out-of-pocket and legal expenses, if any.
The above ceiling got revised on 15/11/2011 to 6 Month Libor + 350 {{Not a typo|bps}} and got further extended on 30/03/2012 till 30/09/2012. From 01-10-2012 Maximum cap of 6 Month Libor + 350 bsp has been extended till further review.
==See also== *[[Trade credit]] *[[Trade credit insurance]] *[[External commercial borrowing]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://buyerscredit.in/ Buyers Credit related articles] * [https://buyerscredit.in/2018/03/13/rbi-stops-buyers-credit-transactions-lou-loc/ RBI Stops Buyers Credit Transactions (LOU & LOC)] * [https://buyerscredit.in/2018/02/20/implication-on-buyers-credit-because-pnb-fraud/ Implication on Buyers Credit Because of PNB Fraud] * [http://www.rbi.org.in/scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=8101 RBI Master Circular on External Commercial Borrowings and Trade Credits 2013] * [http://www.rbi.org.in/scripts/BS_ViewMasCirculardetails.aspx?id=8103 RBI Master Circular on Import of Goods and Services 2013] * [https://buyerscredit.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/all-in-cost-ceiling.pdf Trade Credits for Imports into India – Review of all-in-cost ceiling: Dated 09-10-2012] * [https://buyerscredit.files.wordpress.com/2012/10/trade-credit-for-import-into-india.pdf Trade Credits for Imports into India: Dated 11-09-2012] * [http://www.rbi.org.in/Scripts/NotificationUser.aspx?Id=8229&Mode=0 Trade Credits for Imports into India – Review of all-in-cost ceiling dated July 11, 2013]

page.title: Conservation and restoration at the Smithsonian Institution

revision.comment: Smithsonian American Art museum was repeated, deleted and added the National Portrait gallery (NPG)
revision.text:
'''Conservation and restoration at the Smithsonian Institution''' deals with the [[Conservation-restoration of cultural heritage|care]] of the 138 million artifacts located in the collections of [[Smithsonian Institution]]. Work is conducted by one research center, the Museum Conservation Institute (MCI), and by conservators at the Smithsonian's museums, galleries, zoo. Smithsonian conservators provide myriad services to their units, including exhibit preparation of the museum collection and loan objects,<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Postal Museum|first1=Smithsonian|title=Preservation Projects|url=http://postalmuseum.si.edu/collections/preservation-projects/index.html|website=Smithsonian National Postal Museum|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> advising on object care,<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Museum of Natural History|first1=Smithsonian|title=Anthropology Conservation Laboratory|url=http://anthropology.si.edu/conservation/|website=Department of Anthropology|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> training for future generations of conservationists,<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Zoological Park|first1=Smithsonian|title=Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute|url=http://nationalzoo.si.edu/SCBI/|website=Smithsonian National Zoological Park|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> engaging in routine preventive care on a daily basis,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden|first1=Smithsonian|title=PreventiveConservation|url=http://hirshhorn.si.edu/collection/conservation/#collection=conservation&detail=http%3A//hirshhorn.si.edu/bio/preventive-conservation/&title=Preventive+Conservation|website=Hirshhorn|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> conducting research projects related to the collections,<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Museum of the American Indian|first1=Smithsonian|title=Conservation|url=http://nmai.si.edu/explore/collections/conservation/|website=Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> and examining objects for evidence of manufacturing techniques and previous restorations<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Museum of African Art|first1=Smithsonian|title=Conservation|url=http://africa.si.edu/collection/conservation/|website=Smithsonian National Museum of African Art|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> All conservation labs collectively further the mission of the Smithsonian Institution, "the increase and diffusion of knowledge."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Institution|first1=Smithsonian|title=Mission and Vision|url=http://www.si.edu/About/Mission|website=Smithsonian Institution|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> Founded in 1846 the Smithsonian is the world's largest museum and research complex, consisting of [[List of Smithsonian museums|19 museums and galleries, the National Zoological Park]], and nine research facilities.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Institution|first1=Smithsonian|title=The Museums and Zoo|url=http://www.si.edu/Museums|website=Smithsonian Institution|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Institution|first1=Smithsonian|title=Smithsonian Collections|url=http://www.si.edu/Collections|website=Smithsonian Institution|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>
==Museum Conservation Institute (MCI)== [[Museum Conservation Institute]], the only research center focused on conservation, provides technical studies and scientific analyses for most of the Smithsonian’s collections, and brings unique analytical capabilities to Smithsonian researchers, including a central mass spectroscopy instrument core and advanced technological capabilities.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Museum Conservation Institution|first1=Smithsonian|title=MCI Instrumentation: Supporting Smithsonian Science|url=http://si.edu/mci/english/about_mci/facilities/index.html|website=Smithsonian Museum Conservation Institute|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> MCI is a center for specialized technical collection research and conservation for all Smithsonian units and collections, and these services are available at no charge.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Museum Conservation Institute|first1=Smithsonian|title=About MCI|url=http://www.si.edu/mci/english/about_mci/index.html|website=Smithsonian Museum Conservation Institute|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://www.sil.si.edu/SmithsonianContributions/museumconservation/pdf_hi/SCMC-0003.pdf New Insights into the Cleaning of Paintings” conference held at the Universidad Politécnica de Valencia and Museum Conservation Institute]
==National Museum of African Art (NMAfA)== The [[National Museum of African Art]] houses a state-of-the-art conservation laboratory, which includes a complete x-radiography system with digital imaging. The conservation department routinely collaborates with MCI and other SI units to analyze African art materials, investigate manufacturing processes, and resolve treatment problems. In turn, the department serves as a national and international authority on the conservation of African art.<ref>{{cite web|last1=National Museum of African Art|first1=Smithsonian|title=Conservation|url=http://africa.si.edu/collection/conservation/|website=Smithsonian National Museum of African Art|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref>
===Type of Objects=== The Walt Disney-Tishman African Art Collection.<ref>{{Cite web|title = African Art Museum {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/african-art-museum|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://cool.conservation-us.org/jaic/articles/jaic35-01-001.html Wax Coatings on Ethnographic Metal Objects: Justifications for Allowing a Tradition to Wane by Dana Moffett]
==National Air and Space Museum (NASM) == At the [[National Air and Space Museum]], the Emil Buehler Conservation Laboratory and the [http://airandspace.si.edu/visit/udvar-hazy-center/things-to-do/restoration-hangar.cfm Mary Baker Engen Restoration Hangar] is where conservators devise innovative treatment plans, offer guidance on storage and exhibition conditions, and determine the best possible ways to preserve the artifacts of the National Air and Space Museum which has two locations; one, on the [[National Mall]], and the [[Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center|Steven F. Udvar-Hazy]] Center, in Chantilly Virginia for future generations.
===Type of Objects=== 1903 Wright Flyer, ''Spirit of St. Louis'', Spaceship One, Apollo 11 command module, Hubble Space Telescope test vehicle, pace Shuttle ''Discovery'', B-29 Super-fortress ''Enola Gay'', Concorde, Lockheed Martin SR-71 Blackbird, and Boeing Stratoliner.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Air and Space Museum {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/air-and-space-museum|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Air and Space Museum, Udvar-Hazy Center {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/air-and-space-museum-udvar-hazy-center|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://cool.conservation-us.org/jaic/articles/jaic31-01-009_2.html History, Care, and Handling of America's Spacesuits: Problems in Modern Materials by Mary T. Baker & Ed McManus]
==Smithsonian American Art Museum (SAAM)/ National Portrait Gallery (NPG) == At the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]], the [[Lunder Conservation Center]], serves as the conservation center for three Smithsonian units; the American Art Museum, [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)|the National Portrait Gallery]], and the [[Renwick Gallery]]. Lunder is the first art conservation facility to allow the public permanent behind-the-scenes views of the preservation work of museums.<ref>{{Cite web|title = About the Museum / American Art|url = http://americanart.si.edu/visit/about/|website = americanart.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref> The Center features floor-to-ceiling glass walls that allow the public to view all aspects of conservation work— work that is traditionally done behind the scenes at other museums and conservation centers. Interactive kiosks and special displays make it easy for visitors to learn about the importance of conservation and show how to take an active role in caring for public art and monuments, as well as how to care for personal treasures at home.
===Type of Objects=== Photography, modern folk and self-taught art, African American art, Latino art, New Deal art, impressionist paintings, complete collection of presidential portraits and American contemporary crafts and decorative arts from the 19th to the 21st centuries.<ref>{{Cite web|title = American Art Museum {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/american-art-museum|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Portrait Gallery {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/portrait-gallery|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = The Renwick Gallery {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/renwick-gallery|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://resources.conservation-us.org/osg-postprints/wp-content/uploads/sites/8/2015/02/osg016-02.pdf Blow It Off: Moving Beyond Compressed Air With Carbon Dioxide Snow by L. H. (Hugh) Shockey Jr.]
==National Museum of the American Indian (NMAI) == Conservation for [[National Museum of the American Indian]]'s collection is conducted at the Cultural Resources Center (CRC), the second of three facilities comprising the Smithsonian's National Museum of the American Indian.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Cultural Resources Center {{!}} National Museum of the American Indian|url = http://nmai.si.edu/explore/collections/crc/|website = nmai.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref> The facility is state-of-the-art and includes separate laboratories for working on textiles and objects, a technical library, a photography studio, a scientific analytical lab, and mount-making spaces. In addition, the office actively engages in conservation training—on and off-site— and is committed to conducting research working in partnership with Native Americans on ethnographic and archaeological materials.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Conservation {{!}} National Museum of the American Indian|url = http://nmai.si.edu/explore/collections/conservation/|website = nmai.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Type of Objects=== Wall of gold objects, Geronimo’s rifle.<ref>{{Cite web|title = American Indian {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/american-indian-museum|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://cool.conservation-us.org/jaic/articles/jaic37-03-007_2.html Woven by the Grandmothers: Twenty-Four Blankets Travel to the Navajo Nation by Susan Heald & Kathleen E. Ash-Milby]
== Freer & Sackler Galleries of Art (Freer Sackler) == Conservation at the [[Freer Gallery of Art|Freer]] & [[Arthur M. Sackler Gallery|Sackler Galleries of Art]] is broken into four sections:Asian Paintings, Objects, Paper, and Exhibitions. Conservators are responsible for conducting technical examinations of objects already in the collection and those under consideration for acquisition. They also collaborate frequently with the department’s scientists on technical and applied research. Training and professional outreach efforts are an integral part of the department’s commitment to educating future conservators, museum professionals, and the public about conservation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Conservation and Scientific Research {{!}} Freer and Sackler Galleries|url = http://www.asia.si.edu/research/dcsr/conservation.asp|website = www.asia.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Type of Objects=== South Asian sculpture, Chinese jades and bronzes, modern Japanese ceramics, Chinese paintings, Indian sculpture, Islamic painting and metal-ware, Japanese lacquer, Korean ceramics, Whistler’s Peacock Room.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sackler Gallery {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/sackler-gallery|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Freer Gallery of Art {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/freer-gallery|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://cool.conservation-us.org/jaic/articles/jaic42-03-007.html The Treatment of Chinese Ancestor Portraits: An Introduction to Chinese Painting Conservation Techniques by Valerie Lee, Xiangmei Gu & Yuan-Li Hou]
==Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden (Hirshhorn) == Within the conservation lab at the [[Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden]], specialized activities for the treatment and care of paintings, sculpture, works on paper, and time-based media are performed. As an aid in treatment and to better understand the artist’s creative methods and materials, conservators closely examine works of art using a variety of technical tools, including stereo-binocular microscopes and ultraviolet light. Conservators also use an array of analytical methods to identify under-drawings, pigments, binding media, and coating materials. All treatments involve collaboration with curators, and frequently scientists, to determine the condition of a work of art, guide treatment decisions, and examine the artist’s working methods and procedures.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Conservation - Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://hirshhorn.si.edu/collection/conservation/#collection=conservation&detail=http%253A//hirshhorn.si.edu/bio/conservation-department/&title=Conservation+Department|website = Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden {{!}} Smithsonian|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Type of objects=== In-depth collection of modern masters and works by emerging artists; cutting-edge films; sculptures by Rodin, Matisse, and Moore.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/hirshhorn-museum-and-sculpture-garden|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://www.conservation-us.org/docs/default-source/annualmeeting/2015am_poster_24.pdf Formation of a Long-Term Preservation Plan for a Computer Program by Siebren Versteeg]
== National Zoological Park (National Zoo) == The [[Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute]] (SCBI) serves as an umbrella for the Smithsonian’s global effort to conserve species and train future generations of conservationists.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute - National Zoo|url = http://nationalzoo.si.edu/SCBI/|website = nationalzoo.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref> Ecological processes are highly complex... life and the world are dynamic and ever-changing—it is only with long-term records that many [biological] trends can be deciphered.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Front Royal Campus - National Zoo{{!}} FONZ|url = http://nationalzoo.si.edu/SCBI/AboutUs/FrontRoyal/|website = nationalzoo.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref> The SCBI is the only unit of the Smithsonian Institution exclusively devoted to the study of wildlife conservation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SCBI Front Royal - About Us - National Zoo{{!}} FONZ|url = http://nationalzoo.si.edu/SCBI/AboutUs/FrontRoyal/about_us/|website = nationalzoo.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Type of Objects=== Giant pandas, Asian elephants, white-naped cranes, western lowland gorillas, Sumatran tigers, cheetahs, and North Island brown kiwis.<ref>{{Cite web|title = National Zoo {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/national-zoo|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://globaltigerinitiative.org/ Global Tiger Initiative]
==National Museum of Natural History (NMNH) == At the [[National Museum of Natural History]], the Anthropology Conservation Laboratory (ACL) conducts conservation on the National Museum of Natural history's more than 126 million natural science specimens and cultural artifacts.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History - About the Museum|url = http://www.mnh.si.edu/about.html|website = www.mnh.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref> The ACL provides professional care for collections; reviews prospective acquisitions and loans; prepares collections for exhibit and loan; maintains objects on exhibit in the National Museum of Natural History; reviews sampling requests; advises on object care; and implements preventive conservation projects.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Anthropology Conservation Laboratory|url = http://anthropology.si.edu/conservation/#whatsnew|website = anthropology.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Type of Objects=== Hope diamond, dinosaur fossils, gems, and minerals.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Natural History {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/natural-history-museum|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://cool.conservation-us.org/jaic/articles/jaic35-01-003.html A History of Pest Control Measures in the Anthropology Collections, National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution by Lisa Goldberg]
== National Postal Museum (NPM) == At the [[National Postal Museum]], the Preservation Office is responsible for conservation of the Museum collection.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Preservation Projects|url = http://postalmuseum.si.edu/collections/preservation-projects/index.html|website = postalmuseum.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
===Type of Objects=== World’s largest stamp gallery, full-size Freight-liner semi-truck cab cutaway, vintage mail planes, stagecoach, 1931 Ford Model A postal truck, replica of a railway car; and videos.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Postal Museum {{!}} Museums and Zoo {{!}} Smithsonian|url = http://www.si.edu/Museums/postal-museum|website = www.si.edu|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
=== Conservation Project/Publication === [http://postalmuseum.si.edu/collections/preservation-projects/mailmans-special.html The Mailman’s Special]
== External links== Information concerning prior treatment and housing can be useful to the conservator, and records generated during subsequent treatment can be important in determining future care or treatment.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.conservation-us.org/docs/default-source/governance/defining-the-conservator-essential-competencies.pdf?sfvrsn=1|title = Defining the Conservator:Essential Competencies|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> *American Institute for Conservation|The American Institute for Conservation of Historic & Artistic Works]] (AIC) is the only national membership organization in the United States dedicated to the preservation of cultural material— is a vital resource and tool for conservators at the Smithsonian to foster the exchange of knowledge. The Journal of the American Institute for Conservation (JAIC, or the Journal) is the primary vehicle for the publication of peer-reviewed technical studies, research papers, treatment case studies and ethics and standards discussions relating to the broad field of conservation and preservation of historic and cultural works. * [http://cool.conservation-us.org/index.html Conservation OnLine] (CoOL) is a freely accessible platform to generate and disseminate vital resources for those working to preserve cultural heritage worldwide. The content of CoOL comes from a variety of sources, including contributions from conservators at the Smithsonian.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Smithsonian Institution}}
[[Category:Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:Conservation and restoration]]

{{Infobox sportsperson | name = Danny Hodge | image = A13 2557.jpg | image_size = | caption = Hodge, then aged 80, crushing an apple with one hand at the [[Oklahoma House of Representatives]] in May 2013 | fullname = Daniel Allen Hodge | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1932|5|13}} | birth_place = [[Perry, Oklahoma]], U.S. | residence = Perry, Oklahoma, U.S. | headercolor = lightsteelblue | show-medals = yes | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport | Men's [[freestyle wrestling]] }} {{MedalCountry | {{USA}} }} {{MedalCompetition | [[Wrestling at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]] }} {{MedalSilver | [[1956 Summer Olympics|1956 Melbourne]] | [[Wrestling at the 1956 Summer Olympics|Middleweight]] }} }}
'''Daniel Allen Hodge''' (born May 13, 1932) is a retired American wrestler and boxer. He is renowned for his wrestling career, both [[Amateur wrestling|amateur]] and [[Professional wrestling|professional]]. He was born and raised in [[Perry, Oklahoma]], where he continues to live. He is famous for the ability to crush apples with one hand,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://okgazette.com/2013/05/14/attempting-a-reversal |title=Attempting a reversal: Oklahoma’s wrestling greats grapple with the International Olympics Committee to return the sport to the games. |date=May 15, 2013 |last=Fairley |first=Tim |accessdate=May 19, 2013 |work=[[Oklahoma Gazette]]}}</ref> a feat which he demonstrated live on [[ESPN]] during the [[2006 NCAA Wrestling Championships]]. He said his strength was due to having double tendons in his hands.
==Amateur wrestling career== At Perry High School in Oklahoma, Hodge won the 165-pound title at the state tournament in 1951. As a [[Collegiate wrestling|collegiate wrestler]] for the [[University of Oklahoma]], Hodge was undefeated at 46-0, with 36 pins and reportedly was never taken off his feet during his collegiate career. He was a three-time Big Seven conference champ at 177 pounds (1955–1957), and won the 177-pound title at the NCAA championships those same three years, pinning all three of his finals opponents. (Hodge is only one of two three-time NCAA Division I champs to have done that, the other being Oklahoma A&M's Earl McCready in 1928–1930.) He is the only amateur wrestler to be on the cover of [[Sports Illustrated]] as an amateur wrestler. He worked as a [[professional wrestler]] for eighteen years, and was a 5-time USA Tag Team Champion, with [[Skandor Akbar]], among others.
His reputation as a high school wrestler preceded him when he joined the US Navy in 1951. At Ames, Iowa, in April 1952, Hodge survived the US Olympic Trials, and was coached by Naval Academy Instructor Ray Swartz in the 174-pound division.<ref name=p224>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 224, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> At the Helsinki Olympics, Hodge was defeated by [[USSR]]'s David Cimakuridze. Going into May 1956 wrestling trials for US Olympic team, Hodge was middleweight favorite. He was eliminated on May 2 by William Smith. Smith was embroiled in controversy with the Central AAU and Hodge was his substitute.<ref name=p224 /> After two [[Olympics]] appearances, Hodge placed 5th in 1952, and won the [[Silver Medal]] in 1956, in [[Melbourne, Australia]] after being defeated at the final by [[Bulgaria]]n [[Nikola Stanchev]].
The [[Dan Hodge Trophy]], named after him, is the amateur wrestling equivalent of the [[Heisman Trophy]].
==Professional wrestling career== Trained by [[Leroy McGuirk]] and [[Ed Lewis (wrestler)|Ed "Strangler" Lewis]], Hodge made his debut as a professional wrestler in October 1959.<ref name=p224 /> Hodge's first major feud was with [[National Wrestling Alliance]] Junior Heavyweight Champion [[Angelo Savoldi]]. Hodge's rivalry with Savoldi led to a bizarre event. Hodge's father entered the ring during a boxing match on May 27, 1960, between Hodge and Savoldi, and stabbed Savoldi with a penknife.<ref name=p224 /> Savoldi required 70 stitches at a local hospital, while Hodge's father was arrested.<ref name=p225>National Wrestling Alliance, The Untold Story of the Monopoly that Strangled Pro Wrestling, p. 225, Tim Hornbaker, ECW Press, 2007, {{ISBN|1-55022-741-6}}</ref> On July 22, 1960, Hodge defeated Savoldi for the [[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship]] at the Stockyards Coliseum in Oklahoma City. Hodge became McGuirk's principal headliner, and by 1962, Hodge was making upwards of $80,000 a year.<ref name=p225 />
Hodge was a perennial NWA World Junior Heavyweight Champion, holding the title eight times for a total of over ten years, longer than anyone else. In 2007, Hodge was inducted into the [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]. Hodge has made appearances in [[WWE]] on ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'' in 2005 and 2012 in which he honored fellow Oklahoma wrestling native [[Jim Ross]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-news/36192-wwe-posts-video-of-jim-ross-appreciation-night |title=WWE posts video of Jim Ross Appreciation Night |last=Martin |first=Adam |date=October 1, 2012 |publisher=WrestleView |accessdate=October 1, 2012}}</ref>
[[WWE Hall of Fame]]r and seven-time world champion [[Bret Hart]] has referred to Hodge as "one of the greatest wrestlers in pro wrestling or amateur wrestling there’s ever been",<ref name="baltimoresun.com">http://www.baltimoresun.com/bs-mtblog-2008-07-transcript_of_bret_harts_hall_of_fame_speech-story.html</ref> and described being in the same room as Hodge at the 2008 [[National Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]'s award ceremony as "a big, big honor for me".<ref name="baltimoresun.com"/>
==Boxing career== Danny won the 1958 Chicago Golden Gloves at Heavyweight, then won a Chicago-NY Intercity bout in October, beating Charley Hood. He finished his amateur career with 17 wins, no losses and 12 KO's. Convinced by boxing manager Art Freeman that he was a better prospect than [[Rocky Marciano]], Hodge decided to become a professional boxer rather than pursue the opportunity to compete as a boxer and a wrestler at the [[1960 Summer Olympics]] in Rome, Italy.<ref name=p224 /> In his professional boxing debut, he scored a first-round knockout victory over Norm Jackson.<ref name=p224 /> As a professional, he had a reported record of 8-2, although only 7 wins have been documented. He retired on July 9, 1959.<ref name=p224 />
==Other== On March 29, 2005, Hodge was honored by [[Oklahoma]] state lawmakers as an "Oklahoma Sports Hero".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.postandcourier.com/article/20090510/ARCHIVES/305109918 |title=Hodge has lived the American dream |last=Mooneyham |first=Mike |date=May 10, 2009 |publisher=The Post and Courier |accessdate=April 7, 2015}}</ref> He serves as chairman of the Oklahoma Professional Boxing Commission, which regulates professional boxing, wrestling, and mixed martial arts in Oklahoma.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ok.gov/osac/Oklahoma_State_Athletic_Commission/Commissioners/index.html |title=Oklahoma State Athletic Commission- Commissioners |accessdate=April 7, 2015}}</ref>
==Championships and accomplishments== * '''[[Cauliflower Alley Club]]''' ** Lou Thesz Award ([[Cauliflower Alley Club#2007|2007]]) * '''[[George Tragos/Lou Thesz Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame]]''' ** Class of 2000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://slam.canoe.com/Slam/Wrestling/2003/08/04/153447.html|title=Ventura given Museum's top honour|website=Slam! Wrestling|publisher=[[Canadian Online Explorer]]|date=August 4, 2003|accessdate=November 6, 2018}}</ref> * '''[[Japan Pro Wrestling Alliance|Japan Wrestling Association]]''' ** [[NWA International Tag Team Championship]] – with Wilbur Snyder<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/japan/alljapan/int-t.html |title=NWA International Tag Team Title |accessdate=April 8, 2015 |author=Puroresu Dojo |publisher=Wrestling-Titles.com}}</ref> * '''[[National Wrestling Alliance]]''' **[[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship]] (7 times)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/nwa/world/nwa-j.html |title=NWA World Junior Heavyweight Title |accessdate=April 8, 2015 |author=Puroresu Dojo |publisher=Wrestling-Titles.com}}</ref> * '''[[NWA Mid-America]]''' ** [[NWA United States Tag Team Championship (Mid-America Version)|NWA United States Tag Team Championship]] (''Mid-America Version'') ([[NWA United States Tag Team Championship (Mid-America Version)#Title history|1 time]]) – with Lester Welch<ref name=USTagMA>{{cite book |author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will |title=Wrestling Title Histories |publisher=Archeus Communications |chapter=Tennessee: U.S. Tag Team Title |pages=194 |year=2000 |isbn=0-9698161-5-4}}</ref><ref name=USTagMAWeb>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/tn/nwa/tn-us-t.html |title=NWA United States Tag Team Title (Mid-America) |publisher=wrestling-titles.com |accessdate=April 23, 2015}}</ref> * '''[[Universal Wrestling Federation (Bill Watts)|NWA Tri-State]]''' ** [[Mid-South North American Championship|NWA North American Heavyweight Championship ''(Tri-State version)'']] (3 times)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/midsouth/mids-na-h.html |title=NWA North American Heavyweight Championship (Tri-State/Mid-South) |accessdate=April 8, 2015 |author=Puroresu Dojo |publisher=Wrestling-Titles.com}}</ref> ** [[NWA United States Tag Team Championship (Tri-State version)|NWA United States Tag Team Championship ''(Tri-State version)'']] ([[NWA United States Tag Team Championship (Tri-State version)#Title history|5 times]]) – with [[Skandor Akbar]] (2), Lorenzo Parente (1), [[Luke Brown (wrestler)|Luke Brown]] (1), and Jay Clayton (1) ** [[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship]] ([[NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship#Title history|8 times]]) * '''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''' ** [[PWI Stanley Weston Award]] (1996) * '''[[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum]]''' ** [[Professional Wrestling Hall of Fame and Museum#2007|Class of 2007]] * '''Wrestling Observer Newsletter awards''' ** [[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame]] ([[Wrestling Observer Newsletter Hall of Fame#1996 inductees|Class of 1996]])
<small><sup>1</sup>The records are unclear as to where two of Hodge's eight NWA World Junior Heavyweight Championship reigns began. The records are also unclear as to which NWA affiliated promotion or promotions Hodge wrestled for when he won the championship on those two occasions.</small>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Dead Tired | image = Grosse Fatigue.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Michel Blanc]] | producer = [[Daniel Toscan du Plantier]] | writer = Michel Blanc
[[Bertrand Blier]]
[[Jacques Audiard]] | starring = Michel Blanc
[[Carole Bouquet]] | music = René-Marc Bini | cinematography = [[Eduardo Serra]] | editing = Maryline Monthieux | studio = [[Gaumont Film Company]]
[[TF1 Films Production]] | distributor = [[Gaumont Buena Vista International]]
[[Miramax]] | released = {{film date|1994|5|18|df=yes}} | runtime = 92 minutes | country = France | language = French | budget = $9.5 million | gross = $13.2 million{{cite web |url=http://www.jpbox-office.com/fichfilm.php?id=4257 |title=Grosse Fatigue (1994) |work=JP Box Office|accessdate=5 September 2015}} }} '''''Dead Tired''''' ({{lang-fr|'''Grosse Fatigue'''}}) is a 1994 French [[comedy film]] directed by [[Michel Blanc]]. It was entered into the [[1994 Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2970/year/1994.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Grosse Fatigue |accessdate=26 August 2009 |work=festival-cannes.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110822170809/http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/2970/year/1994.html |archivedate=22 August 2011 |df=dmy }} ==Plot== Michel Blanc is a great film actor. However, he's been accused of sexually abusing actresses Josiane Balasko, Charlotte Gainsbourg and Mathilda May, of behaving like a cad at Cannes and of accepting dubious publicity deals, such as appearances in supermarkets, behind the back of his agent. The evidence is there for everyone to see, but Blanc knows he is innocent. He seeks assistance from fellow actress Carole Bouquet to shed light on this matter, and he discovers that he has a perfect double, Patrick Olivier, who, having suffered all his life from his likeness to Michel Blanc, has decided to use this to his financial advantage. ==Cast== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Michel Blanc]] as himself / Patrick Olivier * [[Carole Bouquet]] as herself * [[Philippe Noiret]] as himself * [[Josiane Balasko]] as herself * [[Marie-Anne Chazel]] as herself * [[Christian Clavier]] as himself * [[Guillaume Durand]] as himself * [[Charlotte Gainsbourg]] as herself * [[David Hallyday]] as himself * [[Estelle Lefébure]] as herself * [[Gérard Jugnot]] as himself * [[Dominique Lavanant]] as herself * [[Thierry Lhermitte]] as himself * [[Mathilda May]] as herself * [[Roman Polanski]] as himself * [[Andrée Damant]] as Madame Volpi * [[Dorothée Jemma]] as The Pregnant Woman * [[Philippe du Janerand]] as Inspector * [[François Morel (actor)|François Morel]] as Inspector's assistant * [[Jean-Louis Richard]] as Psychiatrist * [[Bruno Moynot]] as The driver * [[Raoul Billerey]] as Michel Blanc's father * [[Dominique Besnehard]] as Michel Blanc's agent * [[Bernard Farcy]] as The ANPE employee * [[Vincent Grass]] as The swinger {{div col end}} ==Critical response== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film holds an approval rating of 50%, based on 6 reviews, with an average rating of 6.8/10.{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/dead_tired |title=Dead Tired (Grosse Fatigue) (1995) |website=Rotten Tomatoes}} ==Accolades== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! scope="col"|Award / Film Festival ! scope="col"|Category ! scope="col"|Recipients and nominees ! scope="col"|Result |- |rowspan=3|[[1994 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]] |[[Palme d'Or]] ! | {{nom}} |- |[[Best Screenplay Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Screenplay Award]] |[[Michel Blanc]] | {{won}} |- |[[Vulcan Award]] |[[Pitof]] | {{won}} |- |[[20th César Awards|César Awards]] |[[César Award for Best Writing|Best Writing]] |Michel Blanc | {{nom}} |- |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0109942}} {{Michel Blanc}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dead Tired}} [[Category:1994 films]] [[Category:1990s comedy films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:French comedy films]] [[Category:French-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Michel Blanc]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jacques Audiard]] [[Category:Self-reflexive films]] {{1990s-France-film-stub}} {{1990s-comedy-film-stub}}

{{Infobox artifact | name = Dering Roll | image = [[Image:DeringRoll.jpg|200px]] | image2 = | image_caption = An excerpt from the Dering Roll | material = Paint on [[vellum]] | size = {{convert|264.5|cm|in}} x {{convert|21|cm|in}} | writing = | created = | discovered = | location = [[The British Library]] | id = }} The '''Dering Roll'''<ref>British Library Digitised Manuscripts, ref. [http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_Roll_77720 Add. Roll 77720].</ref> is the oldest English [[roll of arms]] surviving in its original form. It was made between 1270 and 1280 and contains the [[coat of arms]] of 324 knights, starting with two illegitimate children of [[John, King of England|King John]]. [[Sir Edward Dering, 1st Baronet|Sir Edward Dering]]<ref>S.P. Salt, 'Dering, Sir Edward, first Baronet (1598-1644)', ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (2004). [http://www.oxforddnb.com/index/7/101007531/ Online Edition (2008)], subscription needed).</ref> acquired the roll during the 17th century and modified it to include a fictitious ancestor of his own.<ref>A.R. Wagner, ''English Genealogy'' (Clarendon Press, Oxford 1960), p. 310.</ref> It was eventually purchased by the [[British Library]] (as Add Roll 77720) following fund raising involving a number of other charities and individuals.
Glover's Roll, made in 1586, is a copy of a now lost roll dating from even earlier, from the reign of [[Henry III of England|King Henry III]] (1216–1272).<ref>[[James Planché|Planché, J.R.]], ''The Pursuivant of Arms; or Heraldry Founded on Facts'', London, 1873, p.30: "Our earliest heraldic information is derived, at present (1852), from a copy made in 1586 by Glover, [[Somerset Herald]], of a roll of arms of the reign of Henry III"</ref>
==Description== The Dering Roll depicts the coats of arms of around a quarter of the English [[baronage]] during the era of [[Edward I of England|Edward I]].<ref name=artfund>{{cite web|title=The Dering Roll|url=http://www.artfund.org/artwork/10300/the-dering-roll|publisher=Artfund|accessdate=22 May 2011}}</ref> Emphasis was given to knights from [[Sussex]] and [[Kent]],<ref name=artfund/> as it was produced in [[Dover]] between 1270 and 1280 and the document was designed to list the knights who owed [[feudal]] service there.<ref>{{cite news|last=Harrison|first=John|title=Riding to rescue vital record of English medieval knights|url=http://www.mla.gov.uk/news_and_views/press_releases/2008/English-medieval-knights|accessdate=22 May 2011|newspaper=Museums, Libraries & Archives|date=20 February 2008}}</ref><ref name=antiquesgazette>{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Stephanie|title=British Library wins unique key to medieval English heraldry|url=http://www.antiquestradegazette.com/news/6858.aspx|accessdate=22 May 2011|newspaper=Antiques Trade Gazette|date=15 September 2008}}</ref> It depicts 324 [[coats of arms]],<ref name=libraryacquires24>{{cite news|title=British Library Acquires Dering Roll - A Who's Who Of Medieval Arms|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history+%26+heritage/time/medieval+britain/art60428|accessdate=22 May 2011|newspaper=Culture 24|date=2 September 2008}}</ref> beginning with [[Richard Fitz Roy]] and [[William de Say]], two of [[John, King of England|King John]]'s illegitimate sons.<ref name=libraryacquires24 /> The shields are arranged in 54 rows, with six shields on each line. Above each shield reads the knight's name, except in six cases where it has been omitted or removed.<ref name=libraryacquires24 /> [[Stephen de Pencester]] may have commissioned the roll during his time as [[Constable of Dover Castle]].<ref name=antiquesgazette />
==Dering's amendment== [[Sir Edward Dering, 1st Baronet|Sir Edward Dering]] acquired the Roll whilst lieutenant of [[Dover Castle]],<ref name=libraryacquires24 /> and made his modification after 1638, removing the coat of arms of [[Nicholas de Crioll]] and inserting his own coat of arms with a fictitious ancestor named Ric[hard] fi[t]z Dering<ref>British Library, Digitized manuscripts viewer, Add Roll 77720, [http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/Viewer.aspx?ref=add_roll_77720_f001r Image 1], row 11 nos. 1 & 2.</ref> in order to prove the history of his own family.<ref name=artfund/><ref>J. Greenstreet and C. Russell, 'The "Dering" Roll of Arms (continued)', ''The Reliquary, Quarterly Archaeological Journal and Review'' (ed. Llewellynn Jewitt), XVI (1875-76), pp. 235-40, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=TKxDAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA239#v=onepage&q&f=false at p. 239 & note].</ref> This appears adjacent to the shield for Thomas de Marines (''or a cross engrailed gules'').<ref>W.S. Ellis, 'Early Kentish Armory', ''Archaeologia Cantiana'' XV (1883), [http://www.kentarchaeology.org.uk/Research/Pub/ArchCant/Vol.015%20-%201883/015-01.pdf pp. 1-30], at p. 9 & note.</ref>
The trail of Richard fitz Dering (built upon sources dependent upon Dering's collections) leads, or was intended to lead, to the manor of Heyton in [[Stanford, Kent]] (where the connection with the family of Marinis was mentioned by [[Edward Hasted]]<ref>E. Hasted, 'Parishes: Stanford', in ''The History and Topographical Survey of the County of Kent'', Vol. 8 (Canterbury, 1799), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/survey-kent/vol8/pp63-78 pp. 63-78] (British History Online, accessed 11 October 2017).</ref>), and exemplified by charters like that in [[Thomas Willement]]'s hands.<ref>T. Willement, ''Heraldic Notices of Canterbury Cathedral with Genealogical and Topographical Notes'' (Harding, Lepard & Co, London 1827), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=I4NPAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA106#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 106, no. 351, and note 'k'].</ref> A descent through a branch of the [[Nicholas Haute|de Haute family]] of Wadenhall, [[Waltham, Kent]] was then indicated, but Sir Edward Dering's constructive approach to genealogy leaves many of the sources bedevilled by doubts of authenticity.<ref>O.D. Harris, 'Lines of Descent: Appropriations of Ancestry in Stone and Parchment', in T. Rist and A. Gordon (eds), ''The arts of remembrance in early modern England: memorial cultures of the post-Reformation" (Routledge, London 2016), pp. 85-104.</ref><ref>R.H. D’Elboux, 'The Dering Brasses,' ''The Antiquaries Journal'' XXVII (1947), 11–23.</ref>
==Recent ownership== During the 20th century it was acquired by Sir [[Anthony Wagner]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Denhold-Young|first=Noël|title=History and heraldry, 1254 to 1310|year=1965|publisher=Clarendon Press|location=Oxford|page=64}}</ref> On 4 December 2007, the roll was sold at auction at [[Sotheby's]] for the sum of £192,000 to a private individual who subsequently applied for an export licence.<ref name=antiquesgazette /> The [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] placed a temporary block on the roll being moved overseas and the [[British Library]] led efforts to purchase it,<ref name=collegeapril08>{{cite web|title=Newsletter April 2008|url=http://www.college-of-arms.gov.uk/Newsletter/016.htm|publisher=College of Arms|accessdate=22 May 2011}}</ref> after the [[Reviewing Committee on the Export of Works of Art]] confirmed it to be of sufficient importance and significance.<ref name=antiquesgazette /> The library raised £194,184 to acquire the roll; the Head of Medieval and Earlier Manuscripts, Claire Breay said of the purchase, "the acquisition of the Dering Roll provides an extremely rare chance to add a manuscript of enormous local and national significance."<ref name=libraryacquires24 /> They were assisted in funding the purchase from [[The Art Fund]] (£40,000), the [[National Heritage Memorial Fund]] (£100,000), [[Friends of the British Library]] (£10,000), [[Friends of the National Libraries]] (£10,000), and a number of individual benefactors.<ref name=antiquesgazette /> It is now on display at the Sir John Ritblat Gallery in the British Library,<ref name=libraryacquires24 /> and available to researchers in the library's manuscripts reading room.<ref name=antiquesgazette />
==Modern illustrations of arms== <ref name="Brault's Rolls of Arms">{{cite book|last=Brault|first=edited by Gerard J.|title=Rolls of arms : Edward I (1272-1307)|year=1997|publisher=Boydell Press for the Society of Antiquaries of London|location=Woodbridge|isbn=085115669X}}</ref> <gallery> File:The Dering Roll of Arms - Panel 1 - 1 to 54.png|PANEL 1 - 1 to 54 File:The Dering Roll of Arms - Panel 2 - 55 to 108.png|PANEL 2 - 55 to 108 File:The Dering Roll of Arms - Panel 3 - 109 to 162.png|PANEL 3 - 109 to 162 File:The Dering Roll of Arms - Panel 4 - 163 to 216.png|PANEL 4 - 163 to 216 File:The Dering Roll of Arms - Panel 5 - 217 to 270.png|PANEL 5 - 217 to 270 File:The Dering Roll of Arms - Panel 6 - 271 to 324.png|PANEL 6 - 271 to 324 </gallery>
==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Foster|first=Joseph|title=Some feudal coats of arms and others|year=1902|publisher=J. Parker & Co.|location=Oxford|url=https://archive.org/stream/somefeudalcoatso00fost#page/n3/mode/2up}}
==External links== *http://www.bsswebsite.me.uk/History/Dering/dering-roll.html Images of original roll and modern renderings
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{primary sources|date=October 2008}} [[File:Museu efemero.jpg|thumb|300px]]
The '''Ephemeral Museum''' is the first [[ephemeral art]] museum in the world.
It is located in ''[[Bairro Alto]]'', in the heart of [[Portugal]]’s capital, [[Lisbon]]. This museum is sponsored by [[Pampero Fundación]] and it is part of the [[Pampero Rum]] campaign, developed by [[Leo Burnett]] Lisboa advertising agency.
The first '''Ephemeral Museum''' of the world, created by [[Leo Burnett]] for the [[Pampero Fundación]], expands its frontiers. After its inauguration in [[Bairro Alto]], new spots have “opened its doors” in São Bento and Amoreiras, where new and classic talents unite to promote the best of national and international street art. It can be seen after January 29.
In July 2008, [[Leo Burnett]] transformed the streets of [[Bairro Alto]] – Lisbon’s bohemian quarter - into a true outdoor museum. The concept fit in perfectly with the [[Lisbon]] streets, known for being the stage for the [[graffiti]] cult and other forms of street art. In these very streets, the Ephemeral Museum is born.
The [[Museum]]’s success was immediate. Soon, and keeping up the same concept, São Bento and Amoreiras were elected as the new sites for the [[Museum]]’s expansion as a dynamic space in constant growth, with the endless ambition of becoming the world’s largest street gallery.
The idea jump-started when [[Leo Burnett]] set up a marketing plan for [[Pampero Fundación|Pampero]]’s rum, creating a place where everyday street artists could be acknowledged. For this vision to become reality, careful analysis of [[street art]] manifestations had to take place ([[graffiti]], [[stencils]], [[stickers]]) in order to separate true art from vandalism. We identify and catalogue the works (author and title). Most importantly, it makes sense to state that this project is in no means an incentive for [[graffiti]] creation and acts of vandalism (which are normally associated to street art), but as a project that aims to draw attention to the need of a space that voices out and exhibits this style of art as an independent form of manifestation from vandalism, similar to the example in the [[Tate Modern]] Museum, in [[London]].
In the new sites located in São Bento and Amoreiras, it is possible to contemplate the work of various generations of artists from all over the world. The galleries renown such artists like Exas, Creyz, Rote, Eko and Mito, Time, Pariz, Youth, From the Cave, Mace, as well as the international Kenor. [[Bairro Alto]] exhibits the works of international artists Dolk and Jef Aerosol, as well as national artists in the making such as Efeito Magenta and O Colectivo Bitmap.

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = epa european pressphoto agency | logo = [[File:epa-european-pressphoto-agency-logo_480x180039.png|300x300px]] | type = Dutch private limited liability company (Besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid) | foundation = 1985 | location = [[Frankfurt am Main]], [[Germany]] | key_people = Jörg Schierenbeck (President and [[CEO]]), Hannah Hess ([[Editor in Chief]]) | area_served = [[World]]wide | industry = [[News photo agency]] | products = [[News photo service]], [[Stock photography|photo archive]] | homepage = [http://www.epa.eu www.epa.eu] }}
'''European Pressphoto Agency B.V.''' (epa) is an international news [[photo agency]].
[[Image]]s from all parts of the [[world]] covering [[news]], [[politics]], [[sports]], [[business]], [[finance]] as well as [[arts]], [[culture]] and [[entertainment]] are provided by a global network of over 400 professional [[photographer]]s and included in the epa news photo service. The epa picture service is based both on the broad network of epa's staff photographers all over the world and on the daily production of its member agencies, which are all market leaders in their respective countries. All [[photos]] are edited and distributed to clients and partners worldwide by the editorial headquarters in [[Frankfurt am Main]], [[Germany]], which is staffed 24 hours daily.<ref>http://www.epa.eu/products-and-services/epa-service</ref>
== The epa service == epa built up a reputation for reliable, independent and unique photo coverage.
The international picture service of epa is used by diverse [[News media|media]] as well as epa's partners and shareholders worldwide. At present epa’s editorial service offers approximately 2,000 new [[image]]s<ref>http://www.epa.eu/products-and-services</ref> on an average day.
The service includes photographs in the areas of news, sports, arts, culture and entertainment, economy, human interest, and science.
== The epa archive == The epa photo archive dates back to 1997 and has over six million images on stock,<ref name="epa-about">http://www.epa.eu/about-epa</ref> the majority of which can be accessed online.
== History == epa was founded in 1985 by seven European [[news agencies]]. The agencies, [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] of [[France]], [[Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau|ANP]] of the [[Netherlands]], [[ANOP]] (now Lusa) of [[Portugal]], [[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]] of [[Italy]], [[Belga (news agency)|Belga]] of [[Belgium]], [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur|dpa]] of [[Germany]] and [[EFE]] of [[Spain]] were motivated by what they saw as a lack of alternatives to the Anglo-Saxon picture services offered at the time.
Originally conceived as a vehicle to exchange the pictures of the member agencies’ domestic service; it also included the world service of AFP and other European services and suppliers. It expanded to a more independent entity as [[Eastern Europe]] opened up. The opening of these new markets, along with the war in the former [[Yugoslavia]], led epa to employ its own photographers in those regions. Despite these developments, epa remained under the auspices of their member/owners whom it exclusively served.<ref>http://www.epa.eu/about-epa/history</ref>
=== epa shareholders and epa going global === By 1995 epa had ten members with the additions of Keystone later in 1985, [[Austria Presse Agentur|APA]] of [[Austria]] in 1986, and Lehtikuva of [[Finland]] in 1987. Pressensbild of [[Sweden]] joined in 1997 followed by Scanfoto (later Scanpix Norway) of [[Norway]] and Nordfoto (later Scanpix Denmark) of [[Denmark]] in 1999. [[Polska Agencja Prasowa|pap]] of [[Poland]] joined epa in 2001.
In early 2003 after extensive restructuring and the departure of AFP, epa successfully made its service available to the worldwide market. Later in 2003 Lehtikuva, Scanpix Denmark/Norway and Pressensbild (later Scanpix Sweden) decided not to continue as a [[shareholder]] of epa. However, Scanpix Norway, Sweden and Denmark continued cooperation with epa under the name of [[Scanpix]] Scandinavia.
ANA of [[Greece]] (now [[ANA-MPA]]) joined epa as a shareholder in 2004 followed by mti of [[Hungary]] in 2005.<ref name="epa-about" />
Today epa has nine shareholders, all being market leaders in their respective countries:
* Athens News Agency-Macedonian Press Agency ([[ANA-MPA]]) in Greece * [[Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau]] (ANP) in [[the Netherlands]] * [[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata]] (ANSA) in Italy * [[Austria Presse Agentur]] (APA) in Austria * Agencia [[EFE]] in Spain * Keystone in [[Switzerland]] * [[Lusa news agency|Lusa]] – Agência de Notícias de Portugal in Portugal * [[Magyar Távirati Iroda]] (mti) in Hungary * [[Polska Agencja Prasowa]] (pap) in Poland
== Photojournalists == [[Lucas Dolega]], an epa [[photojournalist]], was the first journalist to have been killed during the [[2010-2011 Tunisian protests]] and the first journalist to have died during the [[Arab Spring]] uprisings.<ref>Committee to Protect Journalists. 17 January 2011. “Lucas Mebrouk Dolega.” Retrieved 16 October 2011 [http://cpj.org/killed/2011/lucas-mebrouk-dolega.php CPJ].</ref><ref> "French photographer dies from injury sustained on day of Ben Ali’s departure", Reporters without Borders, 18 January 2011. Retrieved 23 January 2011 [http://en.rsf.org/tunisia-french-photographer-dies-from-18-01-2011,39342.html RSF]</ref><ref>"French photographer dies after being hit by police teargas canister in Tunisia", ''The Guardian,'' 16 January 2011. Retrieved 23 January 2011 [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jan/16/french-photographer-dies-tunisia-protests The Guardian].</ref>
==See also== *[[Associated Press]] *[[Reuters]] *[[Agence France-Presse]] *[[Getty Images]]
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.epa.eu epa european pressphoto agency (official website)] * [http://www.epa.eu/webgate epa webgate (image archive)] * [http://www.ana-mpa.gr Athens News Agency-Macedonian Press Agency (ANA-MPA)] * [http://www.anp.nl Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau (ANP)] * [http://www.ansa.it Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata (ANSA) ] * [http://www.apa.at Austria Presse Agentur (APA)] * [http://www.efe.es Agencia EFE] * [http://www.keystone.ch Keystone] * [http://www.lusa.pt Lusa] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080712083534/http://www.mti.hu/ Magyar Távirati Iroda (mti)] * [http://www.pap.pl Polska Agencja Prasowa (pap)]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox Website |name =Finday |logo = |screenshot = |caption =The Finday homepage |url =[http://www.finday.com/ finday.com]
[[#Domain names|list of domain names]] |commercial =Yes |type =[[Web search engine|Search Engine]]
[[Web directory]] |language =English and Spanish |registration =Optional |owner =[http://www.grupointercom.com Grupo Intercom] |launch date =October 27, 2009{{cite web | url=http://reports.internic.net/cgi/whois?whois_nic=finday.com&type=domain | title=WHOIS - finday.com | accessdate=2010-04-15}} |current status =Active |revenue =From [[AdWords]] |alexa ={{DecreasePositive}} 3,692,469 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/finday.com |title= Finday.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2014-04-01 }} }} '''Finday''' is a social [[web directory]] and [[search engine]] based on [[Google]]'s technology. It provides users a website ranking system that isn't based on statistics but on human criteria (''see below:'' [[#FindayScore|FindayScore]]), and a directory of websites commented and evaluated on by users. The website also includes a large amount of important data concerning each site: who owns it, where it's located, what language it's available in, web traffic figures or its popularity within the ranks of the largest Internet communities among others. ==FindayScore== Finday users can rate with a score from 0 to 10 the most relevant aspects of the sites listed in the search listings. There are different parameters users can use to rate a site based on its content. The current score for each site is listed to the right of its description, this is called "FindayScore". The FindayScore of a website represents the value attributed to it by Finday users. It isn't a simple average based on all the scores the website has received, but a weighted average. This means it's modified by other factors such as its popularity on Finday, loading speed, its traffic according to [[Alexa Internet|Alexa]], etc. In other words, the FindayScore mainly considers reviews submitted by users on the most important aspects of a website, but it's automatically modified by other parameters that contribute to improving the validity of the review. ==Domain names== In addition to the main URL [http://finday.com finday.com], Finday owns [http://es.finday.com es.finday.com] for its localized contents in Spanish. == Company Information == Finday is headquartered in [[Barcelona]], Spain, and it's funded by Grupo Intercom.[http://www.grupointercom.com/ingles/home.cfm Grupo Intercom web site] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://finday.com Finday] * [http://blog.finday.com Finday's Blog] * [http://finday.com/w/finday Comments and Reviews] * [http://wwwhatsnew.com/2009/10/27/finday-un-revolucionario-buscador-social-de-grupo-intercom Wwwhatsnew.com], Launch day press release publication * [http://muycomputer.com/Actualidad/Noticias/Busca-lo-que-quieras-en-Finday/_wE9ERk2XxDDM55YlTkCeGDKINSTSnG7XO58wlUzRah8rGttkzl2jbxDSNyB6WNAN Muycomputer.com], Another launch day press release publication [[Category:Internet search engines]] [[Category:Web directories]]

revision.text:
The '''Frozen Ark''' is a charitable [[frozen zoo]] project created jointly by the [[Zoological Society of London]], the [[Natural History Museum, London|Natural History Museum]] and [[University of Nottingham]].<ref>{{cite news | title = 'Frozen Ark' to save animal DNA | last = Kettlewell | first = Julianna | date = 27 July 2004 | work = BBC News | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/3928411.stm | accessdate = 19 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Endangered species gain a place on Frozen Ark | last = Johnstone | first = Helen | date = 27 July 2004 | work = The Telegraph | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/science-news/3326088/Endangered-species-gain-a-place-on-Frozen-Ark.html | accessdate = 19 July 2010}}</ref> The project aims to preserve the [[DNA]] and living cells of [[endangered species]] to retain the genetic knowledge for the future. The Frozen Ark collects and stores samples taken from animals in zoos and those threatened with [[extinction]] in the wild, with the expectation that, some day, [[cloning]] technologies will have matured sufficiently to resurrect extinct species.<ref>{{cite news | title = 'Surrogate sex' could save vulnerable species | last = Brahic | first = Catherine | date = 13 September 2007 | work = New Scientist | url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn12643-surrogate-sex-could-save-vulnerable-species.html | accessdate = 19 July 2010}}</ref> The Frozen Ark was a finalist for the [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] Award for World Changing Ideas in 2006.<ref>{{cite news | title = Frozen Ark could change the World | date = 23 Jan 2006 | url=http://research.nottingham.ac.uk/NewsReviews/newsDisplay.aspx?id=226 | accessdate = 19 July 2010}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.frozenark.org/}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sUAOBrTD9m0 A video on the Frozen Ark]
[[Category:Conservation projects]] [[Category:Cryobiology]] [[Category:Zoology]] [[Category:Zoological Society of London]] [[Category:Biorepositories]] [[Category:Rare breed conservation]] [[Category:Natural History Museum, London]] [[Category:University of Nottingham]]
